description: From Middle English cours, from Old French cours, from Latin cursus (“course of a race”), from currō (“run”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ḱers- (“to run”). Doublet of cursus and cour.

entries.meaning: A normal or customary sequence.
A programme, a chosen manner of proceeding.
Any ordered process or sequence of steps.
A learning programme, whether a single class or (UK) a major area of study.
examples: I need to take a French course.

entries.meaning: (especially in medicine) A treatment plan.
examples: Miss Clark, alarmed at her increasing stoutness, was doing a course of what is popularly known as banting.

entries.meaning: A stage of a meal.
examples: We offer seafood as the first course.

entries.meaning: The succession of one to another in office or duty; order; turn.
examples: He appointed  […]  the courses of the priests.

definitionGroups.group: A path that something or someone moves along.

entries.meaning: The itinerary of a race.
examples: The cross-country course passes the canal.

entries.meaning: A racecourse.
The path taken by a flow of water; a watercourse.
(sports) The trajectory of a ball, frisbee etc.
(golf) A golf course.
(nautical) The direction of movement of a vessel at any given moment.
examples: The ship changed its course 15 degrees towards south.

entries.meaning: (navigation) The intended passage of voyage, such as a boat, ship, airplane, spaceship, etc.
examples: A course was plotted to traverse the ocean.

entries.meaning: (India, historical) The drive usually frequented by Europeans at an Indian station.
(nautical) The lowest square sail in a fully rigged mast, often named according to the mast.
examples: Main course and mainsail are the same thing in a sailing ship.

entries.meaning: (in the plural, courses, obsolete, euphemistic) Menses.

definitionGroups.group: A row or file of objects.

entries.meaning: (masonry) A row of bricks or blocks.
examples: On a building that size, two crews could only lay two courses in a day.

entries.meaning: (roofing) A row of material that forms the roofing, waterproofing or flashing system.
(textiles) In weft knitting, a single row of loops connecting the loops of the preceding and following rows.
(music) One or more strings on some musical instruments (such as the guitar, lute or vihuela): if multiple, then closely spaced, tuned in unison or octaves and intended to played together.

verbs.description: course (third-person singular simple present courses, present participle coursing, simple past and past participle coursed)

entries.meaning: To run or flow (especially of liquids and more particularly blood).
examples: The oil coursed through the engine.
Blood pumped around the human body courses throughout all its veins and arteries.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To run through or over.
(transitive) To pursue by tracking or estimating the course taken by one's prey; to follow or chase after.
(transitive) To cause to chase after or pursue game.
(colloquial) Ellipsis of of course.
